Treatment might involve radiation for localized bone lesions or systemic therapy like chemotherapy or stem cell transplant, depending on the extent. *[Tool Use: Discuss Treatment Options (Radiation, Chemotherapy, Stem Cell Transplant)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Bone Marrow Biopsy: Shows mildly increased lambda-restricted plasma cells.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The hematology team will determine the best treatment strategy based on all these findings. Managing POEMS can significantly improve the neuropathy and other symptoms. Final diagnosis: POEMS Syndrome.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, what's been troubling you?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: For the past three weeks, I've been getting these high fevers every evening, like 103-104°F. They disappear by morning. I also have really sore joints, especially my wrists and knees, and a sore throat.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any rash associated with the fevers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes! A faint salmon-colored rash appears on my chest and arms when the fever spikes, then fades away.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you had any infections recently? Any swollen glands?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No known infections. My neck glands feel a bit swollen.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, the combination of high spiking fevers, evanescent rash, arthritis, and sore throat in an adult makes me suspect Adult-Onset Still's Disease (AOSD). It's a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning we need to rule out infections, other autoimmune diseases, and malignancies. *[Tool Use: Order CBC with Differential, CMP, Ferritin, ESR, CRP, Rheumatoid Factor (RF), ANA, Blood Cultures x2, Viral Serologies (e.g., EBV, CMV), Throat Swab]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Labs: Leukocytosis (high WBCs, mostly neutrophils), elevated ESR/CRP, markedly elevated Ferritin (>5000 ng/mL). RF and ANA negative. Blood cultures negative. Throat swab negative.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The extremely high ferritin level is a strong clue for AOSD, along with the negative infection and autoimmune markers. We should check your heart as well. *[Tool Use: Order Echocardiogram, Consult Rheumatology]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Echocardiogram: Normal, no signs of endocarditis or pericarditis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Based on your clinical picture and the lab results fitting diagnostic criteria like the Yamaguchi criteria, the diagnosis is Adult-Onset Still's Disease. Treatment typically starts with anti-inflammatories. *[Tool Use: Review Yamaguchi Criteria for AOSD Diagnosis, Start High-Dose NSAIDs (e.g., Indomethacin) or Corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisone)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Still's Disease? What causes it?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: It's an inflammatory condition, likely autoinflammatory, meaning the body's own immune system is causing the inflammation without a clear external trigger. The steroids should help control the fevers and joint pain quickly. Some patients need longer-term biologic medications. *[Tool Use: Discuss Potential Need for Biologic Therapy (e.g., Anakinra, Tocilizumab) if Steroids Ineffective or Required Long-Term]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I hope it works. These fevers are exhausting.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: We'll monitor your response closely. Final diagnosis: Adult-Onset Still's Disease (AOSD).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Your family brought you in because they're concerned about changes in your memory and behavior?

utterances.speaker: spouse
utterances.text: Yes, doctor. Over just the past few months, his memory has declined incredibly fast. He gets confused, his personality changed, and he's started having these sudden jerky movements.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: (To patient) Sir, can you tell me the date today? Who is the current president?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: (Confused, startled by sudden arm jerk) Uh... Tuesday? Is it... Reagan?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The rapid cognitive decline and the myoclonus are alarming. We need to investigate this urgently. Has he had any vision problems or difficulty walking?

utterances.speaker: spouse
utterances.text: He seems clumsier, yes. Sometimes complains his vision is blurry.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This rapid progression raises concern for Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD), a rare prion disease, although other causes need exclusion. We need brain imaging and electrical activity tests. *[Tool Use: STAT Neurological Exam, Order Brain MRI (with DWI and FLAIR sequences), Order Electroencephalogram (EEG)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: MRI: Cortical ribboning and high signal intensity in the basal ganglia on DWI sequences. EEG: Shows periodic sharp wave complexes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The MRI and EEG findings are highly characteristic of sporadic CJD. To further support the diagnosis, we should perform a lumbar puncture to check for specific proteins in the spinal fluid. *[Tool Use: Order Lumbar Puncture for CSF Analysis (including 14-3-3 protein, Tau protein, and RT-QuIC assay)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: CSF Analysis: Positive 14-3-3 protein. RT-QuIC assay positive.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The positive RT-QuIC test, along with the clinical picture and MRI/EEG findings, confirms the diagnosis of sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease. *[Tool Use: Consult Neurology, Consult Palliative Care, Provide Genetic Counseling if family history suggested]*

utterances.speaker: spouse
utterances.text: (Crying) Oh no... I read about that... there's no cure, is there?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I'm so sorry, but unfortunately, you are correct. CJD is currently untreatable and universally fatal, usually within a year of onset. Our focus now is on supportive care, managing symptoms like the myoclonus, and ensuring his comfort. The palliative care team will be very helpful.

utterances.speaker: spouse
utterances.text: Okay... thank you for being direct.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: We will provide all the support we can for both of you during this difficult time. Final diagnosis: Sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (sCJD).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, you were referred for evaluation of bone pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I've had this deep, aching pain in my shins and thighs for almost two years. It's worse at night. Painkillers barely touch it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any other symptoms? Shortness of breath, excessive thirst or urination, skin changes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I do get short of breath sometimes. And I am always thirsty, constantly drinking water.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, the combination of symmetrical long bone pain, possible diabetes insipidus (thirst/urination), and shortness of breath is concerning for a rare infiltrative disorder. We need imaging of your bones and potentially other areas. *[Tool Use: Order Skeletal Survey (X-rays), Order Technetium-99m Bone Scan]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Skeletal Survey: Bilateral cortical thickening and sclerosis in the diaphyses of tibias and femurs. Bone Scan: Intense, symmetric uptake in the long bones of the legs.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The imaging is highly suggestive of Erdheim-Chester Disease (ECD), a rare form of non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The disease can infiltrate many organs, explaining your other symptoms. We need to check other systems. *[Tool Use: Order CT Scan of Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with Contrast, Order Brain MRI (specifically pituitary region), Echocardiogram]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: CT Scan: Shows 'coated aorta' appearance and retroperitoneal fibrosis encasing the ureters. Brain MRI: Thickening of the pituitary stalk. Echo: Mild pericardial thickening.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: These findings confirm widespread involvement typical of ECD (cardiovascular, CNS/pituitary causing DI, retroperitoneal). Definitive diagnosis requires a biopsy of affected tissue to identify the specific cells and check for a common mutation. *[Tool Use: Schedule CT-Guided Biopsy of Retroperitoneal Tissue or Bone Lesion, Request Immunohistochemistry (CD68+, CD1a-, S100-) and BRAF V600E Mutation Testing on Biopsy Sample]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Biopsy successful. Pathology: Infiltration by foamy histiocytes, CD68 positive, CD1a negative. Molecular testing: Positive for BRAF V600E mutation.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The biopsy confirms Erdheim-Chester Disease with the BRAF V600E mutation. This mutation is important because targeted therapies are often effective. *[Tool Use: Consult Hematology/Oncology/Rheumatology (Multi-disciplinary approach), Discuss Treatment Options (Interferon-alpha, BRAF inhibitors like Vemurafenib/Dabrafenib, MEK inhibitors)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Erdheim-Chester... it sounds serious. Can it be treated?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: It is a serious systemic disease, but the discovery of the BRAF mutation has led to effective targeted treatments that can control the disease and improve symptoms significantly for many patients. The specialists will determine the best approach for you.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: That's hopeful. Thank you for finding this.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: You're welcome. Getting the right diagnosis is the crucial first step. Final diagnosis: Erdheim-Chester Disease (BRAF V600E positive).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Good morning. You've been dealing with hives and bone pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, for years. These itchy hives come and go, but the aching pain in my legs, especially at night, is constant. I also get fevers sometimes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Chronic urticaria with bone pain and fevers is an unusual combination. Have you had blood work done recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, my regular doctor said I had some inflammation and a funny protein in my blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, this pattern raises suspicion for Schnitzler Syndrome, a rare autoinflammatory condition characterized by chronic urticaria and a monoclonal gammopathy, usually IgM. Let's investigate further. *[Tool Use: Order CBC, ESR, CRP, Serum Protein Electrophoresis (SPEP) with Immunofixation, Quantitative Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Labs: Elevated ESR/CRP. SPEP/Immunofixation: Confirms presence of an IgM kappa monoclonal protein.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The IgM monoclonal protein with your symptoms strongly points towards Schnitzler Syndrome. We should check your bones and potentially biopsy the skin rash. *[Tool Use: Order Skeletal Survey or Bone Scan, Consider Skin Biopsy for Urticarial Vasculitis, Consult Rheumatology, Consult Hematology]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Bone Scan: Increased uptake in distal femurs and tibias. Skin Biopsy: Neutrophilic urticaria, no definitive vasculitis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The findings fit Schnitzler Syndrome. While antihistamines often don't work well, treatments targeting the IL-1 pathway are usually very effective for the rash, fever, and bone pain. *[Tool Use: Discuss Ineffectiveness of Antihistamines, Initiate Anakinra (IL-1 Receptor Antagonist) Trial]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: A specific treatment? I've tried so many things for the hives!

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, Anakinra often provides dramatic relief for this specific condition. You'll need monitoring by Rheumatology and Hematology long-term due to the monoclonal protein. Final diagnosis: Schnitzler Syndrome.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Your parents brought you to the ER. They say you've been acting strangely?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: (Agitated, speaking rapidly) They don't understand! Thoughts... racing... people watching me...

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: Doctor, this started about two weeks ago after she had a flu-like illness. First anxiety, then this paranoia, memory issues, and yesterday she had a seizure!

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Acute onset psychosis and a seizure in a previously healthy young person warrants urgent investigation for autoimmune or infectious encephalitis. Any abnormal movements? Trouble sleeping?

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: Yes, strange lip-smacking and writhing movements sometimes. And she barely sleeps.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, the combination of psychiatric symptoms, seizures, dyskinesias, and autonomic instability (will check vitals) after a viral prodrome is highly suspicious for Anti-NMDA Receptor Encephalitis. We need immediate workup. *[Tool Use: STAT Vitals Monitoring (for Autonomic Instability), Continuous EEG Monitoring, Order Brain MRI with/without Contrast, Order Lumbar Puncture for CSF Analysis (Cells, Protein, Glucose, HSV PCR, VZV PCR, Autoimmune Encephalitis Panel including NMDAR Antibodies)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Vitals show labile BP and tachycardia. EEG shows diffuse slowing, no clear seizure activity now. MRI brain unremarkable initially. LP performed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Even with a normal MRI initially, we strongly suspect Anti-NMDAR encephalitis. We need to check for an underlying tumor, often an ovarian teratoma, which can trigger this. *[Tool Use: Order Pelvic Ultrasound and/or CT Abdomen/Pelvis, Consult Neurology, Consult Gynecology/Oncology pending results]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: CSF results return: Positive for Anti-NMDA Receptor antibodies. Pelvic Ultrasound reveals a complex ovarian cyst suspicious for teratoma.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The diagnosis is confirmed. Treatment involves removing the teratoma and aggressive immunotherapy. *[Tool Use: Schedule Surgical Resection of Ovarian Teratoma, Start High-Dose Corticosteroids and IVIG, Consider Plasma Exchange or Rituximab if poor response]*

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: Will she get better?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Recovery can be slow, often taking months, but with tumor removal and immunotherapy, many patients make significant improvements. Early treatment is key. Final diagnosis: Anti-NMDA Receptor Encephalitis associated with Ovarian Teratoma.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, you're here because of recurrent episodes of weakness and vision loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes. Several times over the past few years, I've had what felt like a stroke – one side gets weak, vision blurs, terrible headache. But the MRI is always weird, not a typical stroke they say.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How old were you when these started? Any other symptoms like seizures, hearing loss, or muscle aches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Started in my late 20s. I'm 35 now. Yes, I've had seizures with some episodes, and I do have muscle fatigue and some hearing loss in my left ear.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Stroke-like episodes not respecting vascular territories, seizures, headaches, and muscle involvement in a young person suggest a mitochondrial disorder, specifically MELAS - Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes. *[Tool Use: Review Prior Brain MRIs, Order Serum Lactate and Pyruvate Levels (Resting and Post-Exercise if feasible)]*
keywords: mitochondrial encephalopathy lactic acidosis stroke-like episodes

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Prior MRIs show migratory T2 hyperintensities crossing vascular territories, some with restricted diffusion during acute episodes. Serum lactate elevated at rest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The imaging pattern and elevated lactate strongly support MELAS. A muscle biopsy can sometimes show characteristic changes, and genetic testing is key for confirmation. *[Tool Use: Schedule Muscle Biopsy (looking for Ragged Red Fibers and COX-negative fibers), Order Genetic Testing for Mitochondrial DNA Mutations (specifically common MELAS mutations like A3243G)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Muscle Biopsy: Shows Ragged Red Fibers on Gomori trichrome stain. Genetic Testing: Positive for the m.A3243G mtDNA mutation.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The findings confirm MELAS. There's no cure, but treatment focuses on managing symptoms and potentially using certain supplements. *[Tool Use: Consult Neurology/Genetics/Metabolic Specialist, Discuss Symptomatic Management (Antiepileptics, Headache prophylaxis), Consider Arginine/Citrulline Supplementation (especially during stroke-like episodes), Recommend Aerobic Exercise]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Mitochondrial disease... Is it inherited?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, MELAS is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA, which is inherited from the mother. Genetic counseling is important for family planning and understanding risks for other family members. Final diagnosis: MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes) due to m.A3243G mutation.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Good morning. What brings you to the clinic?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I've been having terrible burning pain in my hands and feet since I was a teenager. It gets worse with heat or exercise. I also barely sweat.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: That sounds very uncomfortable. Have you noticed any skin changes? Or had any kidney or heart issues?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I have these tiny reddish-purple spots on my skin, mostly around my belly button and groin. My kidney function is also starting to decline, my doctor said.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The combination of painful neuropathy (acroparesthesias), angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, and kidney disease strongly suggests Fabry disease, an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder. *[Tool Use: Perform Skin Examination, Order Urinalysis, Serum Creatinine/eGFR, Consult Nephrology]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam confirms widespread angiokeratomas. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. eGFR is reduced.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: To confirm Fabry disease, we need to measure the activity of the deficient enzyme, alpha-galactosidase A, and perform genetic testing. An eye exam is also helpful. *[Tool Use: Order Alpha-galactosidase A Enzyme Activity Assay (Leukocytes or Dried Blood Spot), Order Genetic Testing for GLA Gene Mutation, Schedule Ophthalmologic Exam (Slit-Lamp for Corneal Verticillata)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Alpha-galactosidase A activity markedly reduced. Genetic testing identifies pathogenic mutation in GLA gene. Ophthalmology confirms corneal verticillata.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: These results definitively confirm Fabry disease. The lack of enzyme activity leads to buildup of a substance called Gb3, damaging nerves, skin, kidneys, and heart. Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) is available. *[Tool Use: Discuss Pathophysiology of Fabry Disease, Initiate Enzyme Replacement Therapy (e.g., Agalsidase beta or alpha), Consult Cardiology for Echocardiogram, Consult Genetics]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Enzyme therapy? Will it cure it?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: ERT doesn't cure the disease, but it replaces the missing enzyme, helping to slow or prevent organ damage and often improving pain and quality of life. It requires regular infusions. Final diagnosis: Fabry Disease.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hi there. You have swelling near your eye and a swollen gland in front of your ear?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, my left eye got really red and swollen a week ago, and then this lump appeared in front of my ear on the same side. I also feel generally unwell, like I have the flu.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Did you happen to get scratched or bitten by a cat recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Now that you mention it, my new kitten scratched my left hand about two weeks ago. I didn't think much of it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The combination of unilateral conjunctivitis (often granulomatous) and ipsilateral preauricular lymphadenopathy is known as Parinaud's oculoglandular syndrome. In the context of a cat scratch, this is highly suggestive of Cat Scratch Disease caused by Bartonella henselae. *[Tool Use: Perform Eye Examination (Slit-Lamp if possible), Palpate for Lymphadenopathy, Inspect Scratch Site]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam shows follicular conjunctivitis left eye, significant left preauricular and cervical lymphadenopathy. Faint healing scratch mark on left hand dorsum.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This presentation strongly fits. We can confirm with blood tests, although sometimes they take time or can be negative early on. Treatment is usually with antibiotics. *[Tool Use: Order Bartonella henselae Serology (IgM and IgG Titer), Consider Lymph Node Aspirate/Biopsy if Diagnosis Uncertain or Nodes Suppurative (for PCR/Warthin-Starry Stain)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Bartonella IgG titer returned elevated. IgM pending.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The positive IgG supports the diagnosis. Given the oculoglandular involvement, antibiotics are recommended to speed recovery and prevent complications. *[Tool Use: Prescribe Azithromycin or Doxycycline, Counsel on Course Duration, Follow-up Plan]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: All this from a little scratch?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, Bartonella bacteria are carried by fleas and can be transmitted by cat scratches or bites. Most cases are mild, but sometimes presentations like yours occur. You should recover well with antibiotics. Final diagnosis: Cat Scratch Disease presenting as Parinaud's Oculoglandular Syndrome.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, what brings you in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: My ears have been getting really red, swollen, and painful off and on for the past year. Sometimes my nose bridge feels the same way. My joints ache too.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Does it affect the earlobe or just the cartilage part?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Just the firm cartilage part, the lobe feels fine.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Inflammation of the ear and nasal cartilage, along with joint pain, is highly suggestive of Relapsing Polychondritis, an autoimmune disease targeting cartilage. Have you had any eye redness or breathing problems? *[Tool Use: Examine Ears and Nose for Chondritis, Joint Examination, Auscultate Trachea]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam: Bilateral auricular chondritis with erythema and tenderness, sparing the lobes. Mild saddle nose deformity. Tenderness in several MCP joints.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The findings strongly support the clinical diagnosis. Biopsy can confirm inflammation but is often not necessary if the clinical picture is classic. We should check inflammatory markers and rule out mimics. *[Tool Use: Order ESR, CRP, CBC, ANA, ANCA panel, Consider Biopsy of Ear Cartilage if Diagnosis Unclear, Consult Rheumatology]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: ESR and CRP elevated. ANA/ANCA negative.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This fits with Relapsing Polychondritis. Treatment involves suppressing the inflammation, usually starting with steroids. Airway involvement is a serious potential complication we need to monitor for. *[Tool Use: Start Prednisone Therapy, Order Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) with Flow-Volume Loop, Counsel on Disease and Potential Complications (Airway Stenosis, Aortic Aneurysm)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: My cartilage is being attacked? Will the steroids stop it?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Steroids are usually effective in controlling acute flares. Many patients require longer-term immunosuppressant medications to prevent relapses and potential damage to cartilage in the airways or joints. Final diagnosis: Relapsing Polychondritis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Good afternoon. You were referred by your eye doctor?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, she found swelling behind my eyes. I've also had painless swelling of my saliva glands under my jaw off and on for months, and my pancreas flared up recently - pancreatitis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Swelling in multiple different glands and organs like the orbits, salivary glands, and pancreas suggests a systemic fibro-inflammatory process. Have you had any fatigue, weight loss, or back pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, very fatigued. And some dull back pain.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This pattern raises concern for IgG4-Related Disease (IgG4-RD), a condition where IgG4-producing plasma cells infiltrate and cause fibrosis in various organs. We need blood tests and likely a biopsy. *[Tool Use: Order Serum IgG4 Level, Serum IgG Subclasses, ESR, CRP, ANA, RF, Complement Levels (C3, C4)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Labs: Serum IgG4 level markedly elevated. ESR/CRP mildly elevated. Other markers normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The elevated IgG4 is highly suggestive, but not diagnostic alone. Imaging of involved areas and biopsy are key. *[Tool Use: Order MRI Orbits, CT Abdomen/Pelvis (looking for pancreatitis signs, retroperitoneal fibrosis, renal involvement), Consult Rheumatology, Schedule Biopsy of Enlarged Salivary Gland]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Imaging shows orbital pseudotumor, diffuse enlargement of pancreas, and mild retroperitoneal thickening. Salivary gland biopsy performed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Let's review the biopsy results. *[Tool Use: Review Pathology Report (H&E Stain, IgG4 Immunohistochemistry)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Pathology: Dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with storiform fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and increased numbers of IgG4-positive plasma cells (>10 per HPF, IgG4/IgG ratio >40%).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The biopsy confirms IgG4-Related Disease. It's a treatable condition, typically responding well to steroids initially, often followed by steroid-sparing agents like Rituximab. *[Tool Use: Start Prednisone Therapy, Discuss Steroid-Sparing Options (e.g., Rituximab), Monitor Organ Function and IgG4 Levels]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So steroids can shrink these swellings?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, corticosteroids are usually very effective at reducing the inflammation and swelling in IgG4-RD. Rituximab helps maintain remission. Final diagnosis: IgG4-Related Disease.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hi there, you're here for evaluation of recurrent infections?

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: Yes, my son has had repeated bouts of pneumonia since he was a baby, some were really bad and left holes in his lungs, the doctors said. He also gets these awful skin boils that don't seem very red or hot.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Pneumatoceles and 'cold' skin abscesses are quite specific. Does he have eczema? Any characteristic facial features you've noticed?

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: Yes, terrible eczema since infancy. And people have commented he has a 'broad' nose and maybe a prominent forehead.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The constellation of recurrent sino-pulmonary infections (with pneumatoceles), recurrent cold skin abscesses, severe eczema, and characteristic facies strongly suggests Hyper-IgE Syndrome, also known as Job's Syndrome. *[Tool Use: Examine Skin for Eczema and Abscesses, Assess Facial Features, Review Past Chest Imaging for Pneumatoceles]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam shows widespread severe eczema, healing hypopigmented scars from prior abscesses. Mildly coarse facial features noted. Prior CT chest confirms multiple pneumatoceles.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This fits very well clinically. Key lab findings include extremely high IgE levels and often eosinophilia. Genetic testing can confirm the most common form. *[Tool Use: Order Serum IgE Level (Total), Order CBC with Differential (for Eosinophil Count), Order Genetic Testing for STAT3 Mutations]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Serum IgE level > 10,000 IU/mL (markedly elevated). Eosinophilia present. STAT3 mutation testing positive for dominant-negative mutation.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The extremely high IgE and the confirmation of a STAT3 mutation confirm the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Hyper-IgE Syndrome. Management focuses on preventing and treating infections and managing the eczema. *[Tool Use: Consult Immunology/Infectious Disease, Discuss Prophylactic Antibiotics (e.g., TMP-SMX), Antifungal Prophylaxis, Aggressive Eczema Care, Monitor for Complications (Scoliosis, Fractures, Lymphoma)]*

utterances.speaker: parent
utterances.text: So it's a genetic immune problem? Is there a cure?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, it's a primary immunodeficiency. There isn't a cure like gene therapy yet, but vigilant management with prophylactic antibiotics, antifungals, and skin care dramatically improves outcomes and prevents severe infections. Bone marrow transplant is considered only in very severe cases. Final diagnosis: Autosomal Dominant Hyper-IgE Syndrome (STAT3-deficient).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, what brings you in today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I've been getting increasingly stiff, mostly in my back and legs. It's like my muscles are constantly tight, and sometimes I get these incredibly painful spasms that almost knock me over.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Does anything trigger the spasms? Noise? Touch? Startle?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes! Sudden noises or even just being bumped into can set them off. It's making me afraid to go out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This progressive rigidity and stimulus-sensitive spasms suggest a rare neurological disorder called Stiff-Person Syndrome (SPS). It's often autoimmune. Do you have diabetes or any other autoimmune conditions? *[Tool Use: Neurological Exam focusing on Tone, Reflexes, Gait, Observation for Spasms]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam: Marked axial and proximal lower limb rigidity with lumbar hyperlordosis. Gait is stiff and cautious. Reflexes brisk. Spasm observed upon sudden hand clap.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The exam findings are very consistent with SPS. Electromyography (EMG) can show characteristic findings, and blood tests can check for associated antibodies, most commonly anti-GAD antibodies. *[Tool Use: Order EMG (looking for continuous motor unit activity), Order Anti-GAD65 Antibody Test (Serum), Consider Lumbar Puncture for CSF Anti-GAD Antibodies if Serum Negative]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: EMG: Shows continuous motor unit activity at rest in agonist and antagonist muscles, resolving with nerve block/sleep. Serum Anti-GAD65 antibodies: Highly elevated.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The EMG findings and high levels of anti-GAD antibodies confirm the diagnosis of Stiff-Person Syndrome. Treatment focuses on symptom relief with muscle relaxants and potentially immunotherapy. *[Tool Use: Consult Neurology, Start Diazepam or Baclofen for Symptom Control, Discuss Immunotherapy Options (IVIG, Rituximab, Plasma Exchange)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Will these medications stop the stiffness and spasms?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Medications like diazepam are often very effective at reducing the stiffness and spasms. IVIG or other immunotherapies may help address the underlying autoimmune process. It requires careful management. Final diagnosis: Stiff-Person Syndrome (Anti-GAD positive).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Good morning. Your psychiatrist referred you due to persistent fatigue and low mood despite antidepressant trials?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes. Nothing seems to help the depression. I'm tired all the time, constipated, and just feel 'blah'. My thinking feels slow.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you noticed any aches, pains, or issues with kidney stones?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I do get constipated and sometimes have belly aches. No kidney stones that I know of. Maybe some vague bone aches.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Sometimes, subtle metabolic issues can mimic or worsen psychiatric symptoms. The constellation of 'bones, stones, abdominal groans, thrones (constipation), and psychiatric overtones' can be associated with high calcium levels, often from an overactive parathyroid gland. Let's check your calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. *[Tool Use: Order Serum Calcium (Corrected for Albumin), Serum Phosphate, Serum Intact Parathyroid Hormone (PTH), Vitamin D (25-OH) Level, Basic Metabolic Panel (for renal function)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Labs: Serum Calcium 11.5 mg/dL (High), Phosphate 2.4 mg/dL (Low), Intact PTH 150 pg/mL (High), Vitamin D Low-Normal, Creatinine normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The high calcium level combined with a high PTH level confirms Primary Hyperparathyroidism. Your body should lower PTH when calcium is high, so this indicates one or more parathyroid glands are overactive, likely due to a benign tumor (adenoma). *[Tool Use: Calculate 24-hour Urine Calcium Excretion (to rule out FHH), Order Bone Density Scan (DXA)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: 24-hour Urine Calcium: Elevated. DXA Scan: Shows evidence of osteoporosis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The results confirm primary hyperparathyroidism with complications (osteoporosis). This condition can certainly cause or significantly exacerbate fatigue, cognitive issues, and mood problems. Surgical removal of the overactive gland(s) is the definitive treatment. *[Tool Use: Consult Endocrinology, Consult Endocrine Surgery, Order Neck Ultrasound and/or Sestamibi Scan (for Parathyroid Adenoma Localization)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So a neck surgery could help my mood and energy?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, correcting the high calcium and PTH levels by removing the adenoma often leads to significant improvement in psychiatric and cognitive symptoms, as well as protecting your bones and kidneys long-term. Final diagnosis: Primary Hyperparathyroidism presenting with neuropsychiatric symptoms.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: You were transferred from an outside hospital with kidney failure and coughing up blood?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, it started last week with feeling tired and nauseous. Then my urine output dropped, I got really swollen, and this morning I started coughing up blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The combination of rapidly progressive kidney failure (glomerulonephritis) and pulmonary hemorrhage is a medical emergency, highly concerning for Goodpasture Syndrome or severe ANCA vasculitis. We need immediate tests. *[Tool Use: STAT Urinalysis with Microscopy, STAT Serum Creatinine/BUN, CBC, Order Anti-Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) Antibody Test, Order ANCA Panel (MPO/PR3), Order Chest X-Ray]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Urinalysis: Gross hematuria, numerous RBC casts, proteinuria. Creatinine 8.5 mg/dL (markedly elevated). Chest X-Ray: Bilateral airspace opacities consistent with hemorrhage. Anti-GBM Antibody test: Strongly positive. ANCA: Negative.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The positive Anti-GBM antibody confirms Goodpasture Syndrome (Anti-GBM Disease). This antibody attacks both the kidney glomeruli and lung alveoli. Treatment must start immediately to save kidney function and stop lung bleeding. *[Tool Use: Admit to ICU, Place Central Venous Catheter and Arterial Line, Initiate Emergent Plasma Exchange (PLEX), Start High-Dose Corticosteroids (IV Methylprednisolone), Start Cyclophosphamide, Consult Nephrology/Pulmonology/Critical Care]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: (Weakly) Plasma exchange? What is that?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Plasma exchange is a procedure to remove the harmful anti-GBM antibodies from your blood. Combined with medications to suppress your immune system (steroids and cyclophosphamide), it's the standard treatment to stop the attack on your kidneys and lungs. A kidney biopsy is often done to confirm the diagnosis pathologically. *[Tool Use: Schedule Renal Biopsy (for Immunofluorescence showing linear IgG deposition)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Patient undergoing PLEX, started on immunosuppression. Renal biopsy pending.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This is a very serious condition, but aggressive, immediate treatment offers the best chance for recovery, although long-term kidney damage or dialysis may still occur. Final diagnosis: Goodpasture Syndrome (Anti-GBM Disease).

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, what brings you in today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I keep having these episodes... suddenly I feel hot, my skin gets flushed and incredibly itchy, my stomach cramps up, and I get diarrhea. Sometimes I feel lightheaded too.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How often do these episodes happen? Any known triggers? Have you ever felt like you couldn't breathe or passed out?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Maybe a few times a month. Stress seems to trigger them, sometimes exercise. I haven't passed out, but once I felt like my throat was tight.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you have any skin spots or lesions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I have these brownish spots mostly on my trunk that have been there for years. They get itchier during the episodes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, the recurrent episodes of flushing, itching, GI upset, and near-anaphylaxis, especially with skin lesions like urticaria pigmentosa, strongly suggest Systemic Mastocytosis. This is a disorder involving too many mast cells releasing mediators like histamine. *[Tool Use: Skin Examination (check for Darier's Sign on lesions), Order Serum Tryptase Level (Baseline), Provide Patient with EpiPen Prescription and Education]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam reveals multiple tan-brown macules on trunk; stroking one lesion causes localized wheal and flare (Positive Darier's Sign). Baseline serum tryptase level is elevated.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The positive Darier's sign and elevated baseline tryptase strongly support Systemic Mastocytosis. We need a bone marrow biopsy to confirm systemic involvement and check for specific mutations. *[Tool Use: Schedule Bone Marrow Biopsy and Aspirate (looking for mast cell aggregates, atypical morphology, CD25 expression, KIT D816V mutation testing), Consult Hematology, Consult Allergy/Immunology]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Bone Marrow Biopsy: Shows multifocal dense aggregates of atypical mast cells, positive for CD25. KIT D816V mutation detected.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The bone marrow confirms Systemic Mastocytosis. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms with antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers, and having emergency medication (EpiPen). In some cases, targeted therapy against the KIT mutation is used. *[Tool Use: Prescribe Antihistamines (H1/H2 blockers), Mast Cell Stabilizers (e.g., Cromolyn Sodium), Discuss Trigger Avoidance, Consider KIT inhibitors (e.g., Midostaurin) if advanced disease]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So these episodes are from mast cells? Can it be controlled?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, the symptoms are from mediators released by mast cells. With trigger avoidance and medications, symptoms can usually be well controlled, although careful monitoring is needed. Final diagnosis: Systemic Mastocytosis.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: You've been having recurrent swelling episodes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, for years. I get sudden swelling, usually on my hands, feet, face, or sometimes my stomach gets incredibly painful and bloated. It's not itchy, and antihistamines don't help.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Has the swelling ever involved your throat or tongue? Any difficulty breathing during an episode?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, once my tongue swelled up, it was terrifying. I went to the ER.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Recurrent non-itchy angioedema without hives, resistant to antihistamines, and potentially involving the airway, strongly suggests Hereditary Angioedema (HAE), usually due to C1 inhibitor deficiency or dysfunction. *[Tool Use: Ask about Family History of Similar Swelling, Order C4 Complement Level (Screening Test)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: My mother had similar problems, but they never figured it out.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Serum C4 level returned: Low.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The low C4 level is highly suggestive of HAE type 1 or 2. We need specific tests for the C1 inhibitor protein. *[Tool Use: Order C1 Inhibitor Quantitative Level (Antigenic), Order C1 Inhibitor Functional Assay]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: C1 Inhibitor Quantitative Level: Normal. C1 Inhibitor Functional Assay: Markedly decreased activity.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This confirms HAE Type 2 (normal protein level but dysfunctional). It's crucial you have medication for acute attacks, especially given the history of tongue swelling, and we should discuss long-term prevention. *[Tool Use: Consult Allergy/Immunology, Prescribe Acute Attack Medication (e.g., C1 Inhibitor Concentrate, Ecallantide, or Icatibant), Develop Emergency Action Plan, Discuss Prophylactic Therapy Options (e.g., C1-INH concentrate, Lanadelumab, Berotralstat), Consider Genetic Testing (SERPING1)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: There are specific medicines now? That's amazing!

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, tremendous progress has been made. Having rapid access to acute treatment is life-saving, and prophylactic options can significantly reduce attack frequency. Final diagnosis: Hereditary Angioedema (HAE) Type 2.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hello, you were referred for transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I've had several episodes of temporary numbness on one side or trouble speaking. I'm only 35. My brain MRI showed some small old strokes, but the doctors were puzzled by the blood vessel imaging.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Tell me more about the vessel imaging findings.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: They said the main arteries deep in my brain looked narrowed, and there was a 'puff of smoke' look from tiny extra vessels.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Progressive stenosis of the internal carotid artery termini with development of basal collateral vessels ('puff of smoke') is characteristic of Moyamoya Disease (or Syndrome if associated with other conditions). It's more common in East Asian populations but occurs globally. *[Tool Use: Review Brain MRI/MRA reports and images, Order Transcranial Doppler (TCD) Ultrasonography]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: MRI/MRA review confirms bilateral supraclinoid ICA stenosis with extensive basal collateral vessel formation. TCD shows reduced flow velocities in MCAs.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: This confirms Moyamoya pattern. While MRA is suggestive, the gold standard for diagnosis and surgical planning is conventional cerebral angiography. We also need to rule out associated conditions. *[Tool Use: Schedule Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) / Cerebral Angiography, Order Autoimmune Workup (ANA, ESR, etc.), Sickle Cell Screen, Thyroid Function Tests, Consult Neurosurgery, Consult Neurology (Stroke Specialist)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Cerebral Angiography confirms severe bilateral stenosis of terminal ICAs with classic Moyamoya collateral vessels. Workup for associated conditions negative.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The angiography confirms Moyamoya Disease. Given your recurrent TIAs despite likely medical management (aspirin assumed), surgical revascularization is often recommended to improve blood flow and reduce future stroke risk. *[Tool Use: Discuss Aspirin Therapy, Discuss Surgical Revascularization Options (e.g., EDAS, STA-MCA bypass)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Brain surgery? That sounds scary.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: It's a significant procedure, but neurosurgeons specializing in Moyamoya have good outcomes. The goal is to bypass the narrowed vessels and provide better blood supply to prevent potentially disabling strokes. The neurosurgery team will discuss the risks and benefits in detail. Final diagnosis: Moyamoya Disease.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Hi, you're here for evaluation of skin changes and neurological symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I have this strange lacey, purplish rash on my legs that's been there for years. More recently, I've had a couple of episodes like mini-strokes, lasting a few hours.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Let me see the rash. Is it always present? Does it blanch with pressure?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's always there, maybe more prominent in the cold. It doesn't completely disappear when pressed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, this looks like livedo racemosa - broken, irregular rings rather than closed loops. The combination of livedo racemosa and cerebrovascular events like TIAs defines Sneddon Syndrome. It's often associated with autoimmune conditions, particularly antiphospholipid syndrome. *[Tool Use: Perform Detailed Skin Examination, Neurological Exam, Order Brain MRI]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Exam confirms livedo racemosa on lower extremities and trunk. Neuro exam non-focal currently. Brain MRI shows multiple small lacunar infarcts in different vascular territories.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The MRI confirms past strokes. We must test for antiphospholipid antibodies and other relevant autoimmune markers. *[Tool Use: Order Antiphospholipid Antibody Panel (Lupus Anticoagulant, Anti-cardiolipin IgG/IgM, Anti-beta2-glycoprotein I IgG/IgM - repeat in 12 weeks if positive), Order ANA, ENA panel, ESR, CRP, Complement Levels]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Antiphospholipid Panel: Positive for Lupus Anticoagulant and high-titer Anti-cardiolipin IgG antibodies.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The persistently positive antiphospholipid antibodies confirm associated Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), which is common in Sneddon Syndrome and increases stroke risk. Treatment involves anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy. *[Tool Use: Consult Neurology, Consult Rheumatology, Discuss Antiplatelet vs. Anticoagulation Therapy (e.g., Aspirin vs. Warfarin/DOAC based on risk)]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So the rash and the strokes are related? What do I need to do?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yes, they are part of the same syndrome, likely driven by the antiphospholipid antibodies affecting blood vessels. Lifelong antiplatelet or anticoagulation medication is usually necessary to prevent further strokes. The rheumatology team will help manage the APS. Final diagnosis: Sneddon Syndrome associated with Antiphospholipid Syndrome.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Good morning. You were referred by your primary doctor due to anemia and fatigue?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I'm tired all the time. My doctor said I'm anemic, but iron pills didn't help much. Sometimes my urine is dark, especially the first thing in the morning.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Dark urine in the morning can be a sign of hemoglobinuria. Have you ever had blood clots, particularly in unusual places like abdominal veins? Or difficulty swallowing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I had a blood clot in my leg years ago. And sometimes food feels like it gets stuck.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Anemia with signs of hemolysis (dark urine), thrombosis history, and potential bone marrow dysfunction (fatigue, other cytopenias possible) raise suspicion for Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). This is an acquired stem cell disorder. *[Tool Use: Order CBC with Reticulocyte Count, Order LDH, Bilirubin (Indirect), Haptoglobin (Hemolysis Labs), Order Urinalysis for Hemoglobin]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: CBC shows normocytic anemia with high reticulocyte count. LDH and Indirect Bilirubin elevated, Haptoglobin low. Urinalysis positive for hemoglobin.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The labs confirm active hemolysis. The gold standard test for PNH is flow cytometry on blood cells to look for the absence of specific proteins (GPI-anchored proteins). *[Tool Use: Order High-Sensitivity Flow Cytometry for GPI-Anchored Proteins (CD55/CD59) on Red Blood Cells and White Blood Cells (Granulocytes, Monocytes)]*

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Flow Cytometry Results: Significant populations of CD55/CD59 deficient granulocytes and monocytes identified, confirming a large PNH clone.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The flow cytometry confirms the diagnosis of PNH. This condition leads to complement-mediated destruction of blood cells and a high risk of thrombosis. Treatment involves targeting the complement system. *[Tool Use: Consult Hematology, Discuss Complement Inhibitor Therapy (e.g., Eculizumab, Ravulizumab), Discuss Anticoagulation, Consider Bone Marrow Biopsy to assess marrow function]*

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So it's my immune system attacking my blood cells?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Specifically, it's the complement part of the immune system attacking the PNH blood cells that lack protective proteins. Medications like eculizumab block this process very effectively, reducing hemolysis and the dangerous blood clot risk. Final diagnosis: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH).
